That code I provided is just the basic HTML structure needed for Slides to work. You'll need a container DIV with an ID that can be "slides". Next inside the main container div you'll need another DIV with a class of "slides_container". Then with in that put your slide divs. So you'll end up with something like: ```
Slide One
Slide Two
Slide Three
Previous Next
``` And sorry the HTML I provided in the earlier example was incorrect, typing to fast, but this is correct.

Oh, so simple!!!  After spending hours before posting the above, I took a  walk and had another look.
We had to call slides.js within our code in noConflict mode. 

i.e 
                     <script>
                               jQuery(function(){ jQuery('#slides').slides({
                    preload: true, //pre-load images
                    preloadImage: '/images/loading.gif', // loading animation
                    play: 0, // no auto play
                    generatePagination: false, // Stop pagenation from being generated.
                    paginationClass: 'pagination' //Defines the pagination division class
                });
                        </script>

That'll work unless you have multiple slideshows on one page. What you can try is the following. Say you have some links: ``` Slide 1 Slide 2 Slide 3 ``` You can do something like this in jQuery: ``` $('.link').click(function(){ /* Let's get the slide number we want to goto by using what's in the "href" of the link that was clicked and we'll want to remove the hash. */ var link = $(this).attr('href').replace('#',''); /* So now the variable "link" will give us either 1, 2, 3 or whatever we put in the href. */ /* Here's where the fake click happens. We'll find the li with the anchor that we want clicked using the selctor ":eq()", that selector is zero based so 0 = 1, so that's why I do (link - 1). Since we're putting a varible into a string we'll have to use a + operator to concatenate it all together. */ $('#slides .pagination li:eq(' + (link - 1) + ') a').click(); // this just prevents default click behavior return false; }); ``` So with that when you click say this link "Slide 3" jQuery will then click the pagination link 3 and then the slideshow will goto slide number 3. Here's some more info about the :eq() selector: http://jqapi.com/#p=eq-selector

By specifying the `paginationClass` in the options and setting `generatePagination` to `false`, you can have 2 slideshows running with 2 different paginations. I just tested it, and it works great.

```
generatePagination: false,
paginationClass: 'pagination2'
```

Well that is a second bug I wanted to report after this one.
Calling the method to 'navigate' to the same slide as the current one it will fail.

But also invoking `$("#slides").slides("slide", 1)` when the current slide is slide 4 for example.

The number in the invokation will be used to set the `goto` element data on [line 757](https://github.com/nathansearles/Slides/blob/ec4564fa31174e4c1f1fd413ef5047d1d31d1013/source/slides.js#L757) of **slides.js** after 1 is substracted.

Passing 1 as the value to slide to will result in a `goto` value of 0 (zero). Evaluating this value as a boolean, as being done on line 818 will result in false. Because the integer value 0 is treated as false in Javascript.

That's fixed now. Plus you reminded me to add error correction so someone can't enter a number less then 1 or a number greater then the total slides.

I have investigated the issue further today. The bug also appears when any parent element of .slider was set to display: none, then forced to display: block by Javascript. The fix is to force the .slides_container element to display: block before wrapping it in the .slides_control div. I did this by changing line 27 of slides.jquery.js from: 
  $('.' + option.container, $(this)).children().wrapAll('<div class="slides_control"/>');
to 
  $('.' + option.container, $(this)).show().children().wrapAll('<div class="slides_control"/>');
This way, no matter what other CSS or Javascript rules are being applied, the slides_control element will obtain the correct height width and position offset. Hopefully @nathansearles can add this into the production version? If you'd like me to upload my test code, just ask. Thanks.

OK, about 10 minutes after I posted the comment above, the main image in my Slide show (I was using "Product") disappeared again. I implemented the following steps to fix the problem:
1. Go to the following link: code.jquery.com/jquery-1.7.1.js 
   (I removed "http" etc. up to the "//" so GitHub wouldn't remove the link.) Copy the entire contents of this page and save it as "jquery-1.7.1.js" inside the "js" directory inside your particular version of slide. In other words, you'll locate it on your server inside Slide/Product/js/jquery-1.7.1.js" 
2.  Then add the following script info to the head section of your website's page: 
   (Note, in the example below, I am using parentheses instead of brackets, so GitHub doesn't delete the script. Make sure you replace the parentheses ( ) with brackets < > when you insert the script into the head tag area of your webpage. Also, I am working with a Nathan Searl Slide version called "Product" which shows thumbnails (.pagination) as well as a large image (.container).

( script type="text/javascript" src="/slide/js/jquery-1.7.1.js" ) ( /script )

( script src="../Slides/Product/js/jquery-1.7.1.js" ) ( /script )
1. Now you can remove the link to the Google API script source altogether: i.e., the information inside the "script" tags which ends with ".. ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.5.1/jquery.min.js" up to and including the closing "/script" tag.
2. Do not touch the following bit of script, however (once again I've used parentheses instead of brackets around the word "script": 

( script src="../Slides/Product/js/slides.min.jquery.js" ) ( /script )
    ( script )
        $(function(){
            $('#products').slides({
                preload: true,
                preloadImage: 'img/loading.gif',
                effect: 'slide, fade',
                crossfade: true,
                slideSpeed: 350,
                fadeSpeed: 500,
                generateNextPrev: true,
                generatePagination: false
            });
        });
    (/script)

Once again, I hope this helps. It seems to have worked for me.

For version 1.1.9 replace:

``` javascript
$('.' + option.next + ', .' + option.prev).fadeOut(0);
```

with

``` javascript
elem.find('.' + option.next + ', .' + option.prev).fadeOut(0);
```
Looks good. Previous options is cuz is the way that is handled in script $(selector, [container])
Yap, both should work equally
Yep, really needed!

The slides.js script searches the entire page for elements with given class names for the next/prev buttons, pagination, etc... you can update the script and replace all such instances with a jQuery find instead. For example when slides.js tries to find the "next" button:

It does:   $('.' + option.next)
It should be doing:   $(this).find('.' + option.next)

If you get the un-minified version of the script this should only take you 5-10 minutes.

continuous: true

to get infinite loop?

WebKit can do some really funky things when using CSS transitions. I've seen this and many other issues. Unfortunately these issues are apart of WebKits rendering.

In our case, it would help to have an option to disable CSS transitions and use the JavaScript fallback that you use for browsers without support for CSS transitions. I've just checked on our page and there are no weird text rendering issues with the JavaScript method.

I'm thinking something like "transitionMode" with potential values "auto" (= the current behavior), "css" (only allow CSS transitions) or "javascript" (only allow JavaScript transitions).

You can do this using CSS. Don't use negative margin, but try to set the container to position:relative and use position:absolute on the pagination container instead. Hi o-l-e,

For your situation I'd modify the index variable.

The slide number is held in the slidesjs-index attribute. In the first example, the slidesjs-index is part of the image tag but when you add div's to the outside of each image it moves to the div so I changed the var index to get it's value from the parent div. 

``` javascript
var index = $(this).parent().attr('slidesjs-index');
```

I think moving forward with a permanent solution, the block of code will need to be more dynamic so that it finds the slidesjs-index attribute wherever it is in the branch.

    )
